playbook.name: Handle Hello World Alert
playbook.description: This is a playbook which will handle the alerts coming from the Hello World service

playbook.name: HelloWorld Scan
playbook.description:
This Playbook simulates a vulnerability scan using the "HelloWorld" sample integration. It's used to demonstrate how to use the GenericPolling mechanism to run jobs that take several seconds or minutes to complete. It is designed to be used as a subplaybook, but you can also use it as a standalone playbook, by providing the ${Endpoint.Hostname} input in the Context.

Other inputs include the report output format (JSON context or File attached), and the Interval/Timeouts to use for polling the scan status until it's complete.

pack.readme:
This content pack provides the Feed Hello World integration for getting started with your feed integration and the Hello World integration that imports events as incidents.

The purpose of this pack is to learn how to build a Cortex XSIAM content pack.

## What does this pack do?

- Returns domain information and reputation.
- Retrieves alert extra data by ID.
- Retrieves scan status in context or as a file (default) for a scan.
- Starts a scan on an asset.
- Retrieves scan status for one or more scan IDs.
- Searches HelloWorld alerts.
- Updates the status for an alert.
- Returns IP information and reputation.

As part of this pack, you get an out-of-the-box automation, classifiers, incident fields and a Hello World layout. In addition there are two playbooks:
- A playbook that will handle the alerts coming from the Hello World service.
- A playbook that simulates a vulnerability scan using the "HelloWorld" sample integration. It's used to demonstrate how to use the GenericPolling mechanism to run jobs that take several seconds or minutes to complete.

pack.name: Microsoft Teams
pack.description: Send messages and notifications to your team members.
pack.author: Cortex XSIAM

automation.name: ConfigureAzureApplicationAccessPolicy
automation.description: This script grants a user the permissions needed to create a Teams meeting. It connects to MS Teams, creating an application access policy to a chosen application and then grants a user permissions.

automation.name: MicrosoftTeamsAsk
automation.description: Send a team member or channel a question with predefined response options on Microsoft Teams. The response can be used to close a task (might be conditional) in a playbook.

integration.name: Microsoft Teams via Webhook
integration.description: Integration for sending notifications to a Microsoft Teams channel via Incoming Webhook.

commands.name: ms-teams-message
commands.description: Send a message to Microsoft Teams via Incoming Webhook

integration.name: Microsoft Teams Management
integration.description: Manage teams and members in Microsoft Teams.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-auth-start
commands.description: Run this command to start the authorization process and follow the instructions in the command results.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-auth-complete
commands.description:
Run this command to complete the authorization process.
Should be used after running the microsoft-teams-auth-start command.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-auth-reset
commands.description: Run this command if for some reason you need to rerun the authentication process.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-auth-test
commands.description: Tests connectivity to Microsoft.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-create
commands.description: Creates a new team.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-create-from-group
commands.description: Create a new team under a group. In order to create a team, the group must have a least one owner and the group cannot be of type Security.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-teams-list
commands.description: Returns all the groups that have teams in an organization.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-update
commands.description: Update the properties of the specified team.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-delete
commands.description: Deletes a group. Note: it might take time for the team to disappear from the teams list.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-get
commands.description: Retrieve the properties and relationships of the specified team.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-members-list
commands.description: Returns the members of the specified team.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-member-get
commands.description: Gets a member of a team.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-member-add
commands.description: Add a user to be a team member.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-member-remove
commands.description: Remove a member from the team.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-member-update
commands.description: Updates a team member.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-archive
commands.description: Archive the specified team. When a team is archived, users can no longer send or like messages on any channel in the team, edit the team's name, description, or other settings, or in general make most changes to the team. Membership changes to the team continue to be allowed. Archiving is an async operation. A team is archived once the async operation completes successfully, which may occur subsequent to a response from this command. In order to archive a team, the team and group must have an owner.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-unarchive
commands.description: Restore an archived team. This restores the users' ability to send messages and edit the team, abiding by tenant and team settings. Unarchiving is an async operation. A team is unarchived once the async operation completes successfully, which may occur subsequent to a response from this command.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-team-clone
commands.description: Create a copy of a team. This operation also creates a copy of the corresponding group. Cloning is a long-running operation.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-teams-list-joined
commands.description: Get the teams in Microsoft Teams that the user is a direct member of.

integration.name: Microsoft Teams
integration.description: Send messages and notifications to your team members.

commands.name: send-notification
commands.description:
Sends a message to the specified teams.
To mention a user in the message, add a semicolon ";" at the end of the user mention. For example: @Bruce Willis;

commands.name: mirror-investigation
commands.description: Mirrors the XSOAR investigation to the specified Microsoft Teams channel. Supports only standard channels.

commands.name: close-channel
commands.description: Deletes the specified Microsoft Teams channel.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-integration-health
commands.description: Returns real-time and historical data on the integration status.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-auth-test
commands.description: Tests the connectivity to MicrosoftTeams.

commands.name: create-channel
commands.description: Creates a new channel in a Microsoft Teams team.

commands.name: add-user-to-channel
commands.description: Adds a member (user) to a private/shared channel.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-ring-user
commands.description: Ring a user's Teams account. Note: This is a ring only! no media will play in case the generated call is answered. To use this make sure your Bot has the following permissions - Calls.Initiate.All and Calls.InitiateGroupCall.All

commands.name: microsoft-teams-add-user-to-channel
commands.description: Adds a member (user) to a private/shared channel.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-create-channel
commands.description: Creates a new channel in a Microsoft Teams team.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-create-meeting
commands.description: Creates a new meeting in Microsoft Teams.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-user-remove-from-channel
commands.description: Removes a member (user) from a private/shared channel.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-channel-user-list
commands.description: Retrieves a list of members from a channel.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-chat-create
commands.description:
Creates a new chat. 
Note: Only one oneOnOne chat can exist between two members. If a oneOnOne chat already exists, it will be returned.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-message-send-to-chat
commands.description: Sends a new chat message in the specified chat.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-chat-add-user
commands.description: Adds a member (user) to a group chat.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-chat-member-list
commands.description: Retrieves a list of members from a chat.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-chat-message-list
commands.description: Retrieves a list of messages in a chat.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-chat-list
commands.description: Retrieves a list of chats that the user is part of. If 'chat' is specified, retrieves this chat only.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-chat-update
commands.description: Updates the chat name. It can only be set for group chats.

commands.name: microsoft-teams-generate-login-url
commands.description: Generate the login url used for Authorization code flow.

pack.name: AWS - Security Hub
pack.description: Amazon Web Services Security Hub Service.
pack.author: Cortex XSOAR

integration.name: AWS - Security Hub
integration.description: Amazon Web Services Security Hub Service.

commands.name: aws-securityhub-disable-security-hub
commands.description: Disables Security Hub in your account only in the current Region. To disable Security Hub in all Regions, you must submit one request per Region where you have enabled Security Hub. When you disable Security Hub for a master account, it doesn't disable Security Hub for any associated member accounts. When you disable Security Hub, your existing findings and insights and any Security Hub configuration settings are deleted after 90 days and can't be recovered. Any standards that were enabled are disabled, and your master and member account associations are removed. If you want to save your existing findings, you must export them before you disable Security Hub.

commands.name: aws-securityhub-batch-update-findings
commands.description: Used by Security Hub customers to update information about their investigation into a finding. Requested by master accounts or member accounts. Master accounts can update findings for their account and their member accounts. Member accounts can update findings for their account. Updates from BatchUpdateFindings do not affect the value of UpdatedAt for a finding. Master accounts can use BatchUpdateFindings to update the following finding fields and objects. *   Confidence *   Criticality *   Note *   RelatedFindings *   Severity *   Types *   UserDefinedFields *   VerificationState *   Workflow Member accounts can only use BatchUpdateFindings to update the Note object.

commands.name: aws-securityhub-enable-security-hub
commands.description: Enables Security Hub for your account in the current Region or the Region you specify in the request. Enabling Security Hub also enables the CIS AWS Foundations standard. When you enable Security Hub, you grant to Security Hub the permissions necessary to gather findings from AWS Config, Amazon GuardDuty, Amazon Inspector, and Amazon Macie. To learn more, see Setting Up AWS Security Hub.

commands.name: aws-securityhub-get-findings
commands.description: Returns a list of findings that match the specified criteria.

commands.name: aws-securityhub-get-master-account
commands.description: Provides the details for the Security Hub master account to the current member account.

commands.name: aws-securityhub-list-members
commands.description: Lists details about all member accounts for the current Security Hub master account.

commands.name: aws-securityhub-update-findings
commands.description: Deprecated, use aws-securityhub-batch-update-findings instead.

commands.name: get-remote-data
commands.description: Get remote data from a remote incident. This method does not update the current incident, and should be used for debugging purposes only.

commands.name: get-mapping-fields
commands.description: Returns the list of fields to map in outgoing mirroring. This command is only used for debugging purposes.

incidentfield.name: AWS Security Hub User Defined Fields
AWS Security Hub Threat Intel Indicators
AWS Security Hub Provider Updated At

pack.readme:
AWS Security Hub is a service that performs security best practice checks, aggregates alerts, and enables automated remediation. The service helps you analyze security trends in your environment, and helps you identify the highest priority security issues. It provides you with a comprehensive view of the security state of your AWS environment and resources, along with the compliance status of your environment, based on CIS AWS Foundations compliance checks. AWS Security Hub collects security data from AWS accounts, services, and integrated third-party products. 

**What does this pack do?**
This pack enables you to:
- Disable Security Hub for the current region.
- Update finding fields and objects in order to refresh the information required for investigating a Security Hub finding.
- Enable Security Hub for your account in the current region or the region you specify in the request, and the CIS AWS Foundations standard.
- Return a list of findings that match the specified criteria.
- Provide AWS Security Hub master account details to the current member account.
- List details about all member accounts for the current AWS Security Hub master account.

pack.name: Access Investigation
pack.description: This Content Pack automates response to unauthorised access incidents and contains customer access incident views and layouts to aid investigation.
pack.author: Cortex XSIAM

playbook.name: Access Investigation - Generic
playbook.description:
This playbook investigates an access alert by gathering user and IP information.

The playbook then interacts with the user that triggered the alert to confirm whether or not they initiated the access action.

pack.readme:
An unauthorised access to a cloud asset, a server or a physical endpoint can compromise an entire organization. 
Access investigations require security teams to reconcile data from multiple sources, gather user and network data, and communicate with users and other relevant parties. Valuable time is lost shuttling between screens and executing repeatable tasks while an attack continues to manifest.
This Access Investigation content pack contains the Access Investigation - Generic playbook, that automates response to an unauthorised access incident. The pack also contains the corresponding custom Access incident type to facilitate analyst investigation.
The Access playbook orchestrates across multiple products to extract and enrich IOCs, interact with the suspected user and calculate the incidents severity.


##### What does this pack do?
The playbooks included in this pack help you save time and automate repetitive tasks associated with Malware incidents:
- Create an Access incident within Cortex XSIAM associated with the unauthorized access.
- Extract and enrich user information, and retrieve the users manager details.
- Extract and enrich IP information.
- Interact with the user to gather more information regarding the suspected access.
- Calculate the incidents severity based on the enriched information and information received from the user.
- Assign the investigation to an analyst.

As part of this pack, you will also get out-of-the-box Access incident type, which is easily customizable to suit the needs of your organization.

_For more information, visit our  [Cortex XSIAM Developer Docs](https://xsoar.pan.dev/docs/reference/playbooks/access-investigation---generic)_

![Access_Investigation_-_Generic](https://storage.googleapis.com/marketplace-v2-dist/content/packs/AccessInvestigation/readme_images/Access_Investigation_-_Generic_4_5.png)
